# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia solution for your problem:

```julia
using DataFrames, DataStructures

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    filter!(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    insertcols!(df, :new => trues(size(df)[1]), :new)
    return df
end
```

This function works by first using the `filter!` function to keep only rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". This creates a new DataFrame with the desired properties. Then, it uses the `insertcols!` function to insert a new column of `trues`. This column will be equal across all rows because we have already filtered out any rows where this condition is not met.

You can call the function like so:
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"], 
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
